package.name: Plop
package.description: PLOP is a port of Python's logging module to PHP.
package.notes:
Release notes for Plop version 0.2.0 ------------------------------------
Plop is now structured using PEAR2's standard directory layout. This way, it can be packaged as a PEAR2 package.
The latest (packaged) version of Plop will be available on Erebot's pear repository (pear.erebot.net). Follow the instructions at http://pear.erebot.net/ to install it.
Nothing else was changed in this release, but due to the numerous compatibility breaks this caused, there was a need for a new minor release.
API release notes for Plop version 0.2.0 ----------------------------------------
This version of Plop breaks backward compatibility as it uses a PEAR2-oriented directory layout. You'll need to adapt
An auto-loader was added so that you don't need to worry about where the classes are.
The classes have been renamed to (somewhat) follow PEAR's naming conventions. For example, the stream handler class is now called Plop_Handler_Stream. Also, the classes for configuration parsers were also renamed (Plop_Config_Format_INI and Plop_Config_Format_XML). As a result,
This affects configuration files a little as the class names need to be updated. Other than that, usage has not really changed, even though the main file was renamed to.
To sum it up, the snippets below show how Plop was used and how it must be used from now on.
Old usage: 1. Include "logging.php" from Plop's sources. 2. Use $logging =& Plop::getInstance(); to retrieve an instance of the logging subsystem. 3. Configure logging, eg. with: $logging->fileConfig( $configPath, array(), 'XML' ); 4. Use $logger = $logging->getLogger(__FILE__); to retrieve a logger for the current file. 5. Log whatever you want with eg. $logger->error('Ouch!');
New usage: 1. Include "Plop.php" from Plop's sources. 2. Use $logging =& Plop::getInstance(); to retrieve an instance of the logging subsystem. 3. Configure logging, eg. with: $logging->fileConfig( $configPath, array(), 'Plop_Config_Format_XML' ); 4. Use $logger = $logging->getLogger(__FILE__); to retrieve a logger for the current file. 5. Log whatever you want with eg. $logger->error('Ouch!');
So, as you can see, only the include statement and the 3rd argument to Plop::fileConfig() have been modified.
